environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: In a greenhouse experiment with sandy loam soil treated with 0-8.0 ppm boron as borax, boron toxicity symptoms appeared earliest in lentil plants and barley seedlings exposed to 8.0 ppm boron. In barley the severity of boron toxicity decreased with the decrease in boron levels, whereas in lentil the severity of the symptoms eventually reached the same level in 2 and 4 ppm boron treatments as with the highest concentration. Dry matter yield decreased 38.6% in lentil and 23.4% in barley exposed to 8.0 ppm boron in comparison with controls. Boron contents of lentil and barley plants on soil treated with 8 ppm boron were approximately 7- and approximately 8-fold those of control plants, respectively.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Boron has well-defined biological effects and may be of therapeutic benefit. In the current paper, the effect of boron in the form of borax was tested in experimental animal model of fulminant hepatic failure (FHF). The syndrome was induced in female Wistar rats by three consecutive daily intraperitoneal injections of thioacetamide (400 mg/kg). In the treatment groups, rats received borax (4.0 mg/kg) orally for three consecutive days followed by thioacetamide. The group administered with thioacetamide plus vehicle, and the borax alone treated rats served as controls. In all groups, rats were terminated 4 hr after administering the last dose of thioacetamide, and the tissue/serum was used to measure hepatic levels of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances, reduced glutathione, and various enzymes associated with oxidative stress including peroxide metabolizing enzymes and xanthine oxidase. In thioacetamide treated group, many fold increase in the activity level of serum marker enzymes suggesting FHF was observed that could be brought down significantly in rats receiving boron. Modulation and a correlation in the activity level of oxidant generating enzyme and lipid peroxidation as well as hepatic glutathione level was also observed in rats receiving thioacetamide. In the group receiving boron followed by thioacetamide, these changes could be minimized moderately. The activity level of the peroxide metabolizing enzymes and the tripeptide glutathione, which decreased following thioacetamide treatment were moderately elevated in the group receiving boron followed by thioacetamide. The data clearly shows that borax partly normalizes the liver and offsets the deleterious effects observed in FHF by modulating the oxidative stress parameters.

/LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ The aims of this study were to clarify the effects of high dietary supplementation with boric acid and borax, called boron (B) compounds, on lipid peroxidation (LPO), antioxidant activity, some vitamin levels, and DNA damage in rats. Thirty Sprague Dawley male rats were divided into three equal groups: the animals in the first group (control) were fed with a standard rodent diet containing 6.4 mg/kg /boron/, and the animals in the experimental group were fed with a standard rodent diet added with a supra-nutritional amount of boric acid and borax (100 mg/kg /boron/) throughout the experimental period of 28 days. The B compounds decreased malondialdehyde (MDA), DNA damage, the protein carbonyl content (PCO) level in blood, and glutathione (GSH) concentration in the liver, Cu-Zn superoxide dismutase (SOD), and catalase (CAT) activity in the kidney. The B compounds increased GSH concentration in blood and the vitamin C level in plasma. Consequently, our results demonstrate that B supplementation (100 mg/kg) in diet decreases LPO, and enhances the antioxidant defense mechanism and vitamin status. There are no differences in oxidant/antioxidant balance and biochemical parameters except for serum vitamin A and liver GSH concentration, between the boron compounds used in this study.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ A diet of borax or boric acid was administered to Sprague Dawley rats (10/sex/dose) for 90 days at doses of 0, 52.5, 175, 525, 1,750 or 5,250 ppm as boron equivalents. Both borax and boric acid produced 100% mortality at the highest dose and complete atrophy of the testes in all males fed diets containing 1,750 ppm boron equivalent. At 1,750 ppm boron, both compounds produced significant decreases in body weight and in the mean weights of the liver, kidney, spleen, and testes. At 52.5 ppm boron, borax produced increases in the mean weights of the spleen, kidneys, and ovaries in females, and boric acid produced an increase in liver mean weight. These changes, however, were not observed at 525 ppm boron for either compound. Microscopic examination revealed partial testicular atrophy at 525 ppm boron in four males fed borax and in one male fed boric acid.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ Concentrations of 0, 500, 1,000 or 2,000 mg boron/kg diet, were fed as borax, to male Sprague Dawley rats (18/group) for 60 days. Testicular and plasma levels of boron were elevated in dose dependent fashion at 30 and 60 days of treatment. Significant decreases in the weights of liver, testes, and epididymis were observed at the 1,000 and 2,000 mg boron/kg dietary levels. Seminiferous tubule diameter was significantly decreased in a dose-dependent manner in all treatment groups; however, loss of germinal cell elements was observable only at the 1,000 or 2,000 mg boron/kg dietary level. Aplasia was complete at the highest dose. The testicular activities of hyaluronidase (H) and sorbitol dehydrogenase (SDH), enzymes associated with postmeiotic spermatogenic cells, were significantly decreased in an apparent dose-related fashion for all treatment levels. The related testicular enzyme, lactic acid dehydrogenase, although decreased at the 500 mg boron/kg dietary level, was significantly decreased only at the two higher dose levels. Plasma levels of the hormone FSH were significantly elevated in a dose dependent fashion at all dose levels. Serial mating studies revealed reduced fertility without change in copulatory behavior only at the two higher dose levels.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ Groups of 18 male rats were placed on diets containing 0-2,000 ppm boron as sodium borate (about 0-1.06 g/kg/day sodium borate). At 30 and 60 days, 5 rats from each group were mated to assess fertility, 10 rats were used to determine hormone concentrations, and 3 were used to evaluate enzyme activities, histopathologic changes, and organ weights. Throughout the study, no animals showed signs of systemic toxicity. Body and organ weights, as well as food consumption, were normal. At 1000 and 2000 ppm boron (about 0.53 and 1.06 g/kg/day sodium borate), the following gonadal effects were observed: reduced testicular weight (60 days); decreased epididymal weight (30 days); reductions in spermatocytes, spermatids, tubular diameter, and numbers of mature spermatozoa (30 days); and germinal aplasia (60 days). Dose dependent reductions in hyaluronidase, sorbital dehydrogenase, and lactic acid dehydrogenase isoenzyme-x were observed at 30 days. At 2000 ppm boron, increased FSH and LH concentrations were reported; FSH levels were still above normal 12 months post-feeding. Rats given dietary concentrations of 1000 ppm boron for 30 days, 1000 ppm boron for 60 days (about 0.53 g/kg/day sodium borate), and 2000 ppm boron for 30 days (about 1.06 g/kg/day sodium borate) were infertile for 3, 4, and 8 weeks post-feeding. Rats receiving 2000 ppm boron for 60 days (about 1.06 g/kg/day sodium borate) remained infertile throughout the 32 wk mating trials.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ The toxicology of the inorganic borates boric-acid (10043353), borax (1303964), boric-oxide (1303862), sodium-perborate-tetrahydrate (10486007), sodium-perborate-monohydrate (10332339), borax-pentahydrate (12179043), and anhydrous-borax (1330434) was reviewed, and a risk assessment for man was conducted. The toxicological end points of concern identified for both boric-acid and borax from animal studies were fertility and developmental toxicity. The lowest no observed adverse effect level for fertility in male and female rats was 17mg/kg boron (7440428) for both boric-acid and borax. Effects observed at the low observed adverse effect level included testicular toxicity, reduced spermiation in males and decreased ovulation in females. Testicular atrophy was noted at higher doses. Only boric-acid data was available for developmental toxicity from rat, mouse, and rabbit studies. The most sensitive species was the rat with a no observed adverse effect level of 0.5mg/kg boron, based on reduced fetal body weight and skeletal effects. A tolerable daily intake of borates for a 60 kilogram person was calculated to be 34 milligrams (mg) boron/day and 19.2mg boron/day which could be ingested without the risk of fertility or developmental effects, respectively. Considering that the maximum boron intake from the diet is 7mg/day from food, mineral waters, and other beverages including wine, up to 12mg boron could be obtained from other resources without exceeding the daily intake limit.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /ENDOCRINE MODULATION/ The toxic effects of boronated compounds were examined by reviewing human and animal knowledge regarding general, genetic, carcinogenic, reproductive, endocrine, and developmental toxicities. These compounds have been found to be toxic at high doses to all species tested. No evidence of genotoxicity, carcinogenicity, or mutagenicity has been identified. In extensive studies using boric-acid (10043353) and borax (1303964), both of these compounds were shown to have reproductive toxicity in rats and mice, although no definitive studies have been reported for humans. Changes in testicular characteristics following exposure to boric-acid suggested the involvement of an endocrine mechanism. This idea was supported by early studies showing increased blood follicle stimulating hormone levels and depressed testosterone in rodents exposed to borax or boric-acid. Subsequent studies have suggested that hormonal changes are secondary to germ cell changes. Developmental changes following exposure to relatively low levels of boric-acid have been reported in rats, mice, rabbits, and birds. Human risk assessments do not suggest a likelihood of human toxicity from boron-containing inorganics.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /IMMUNOTOXICITY/ Apoptosis has gained increasing attention in recent years. Several chemical compounds induce apoptotic lesions in the thymus. Male Wistar rats received 2000 ppm of borax (Na2B4O7.10H2O) in their food for 16 days. The rats were sacrificed 2, 5, 9, 12, 16, 19, 21, 26 and 28 days after the beginning of treatment. Thymus samples of all rats were taken. A Philips EM 300 electron microscopy was used to study the ultrastructural morphology. Serious nuclear and cytoplasmic lesions were observed. Moreover, numerous macrophages containing apoptotic cells were present in the thymus. The alterations were observed from the 2th to the 28th day. The extent of damage was much more important in the rats sacrificed 21, 26 and 28 days after borax ingestion.

/OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/ Based on the inhibition effect on the respiratory chain activity of microorganisms by toxicants, an electrochemical method has been developed to measure the current variation of a mediator in the presence of microorganisms contacted with a toxicant. Microelectrode arrays were adopted in this study, which can accelerate the mass transfer rate of an analyte to the electrode and also increase the total current signal, resulting in an improvement in detection sensitivity. /The authors/ selected Escherichia coli as the testee and the standard glucose-glutamic acid as an exogenous material. Under oxygen restriction, the experiments in the presence of toxicant were performed at optimum conditions (solution pH 7.0, 37 degrees C and reaction for 3 hr). The resulting solution was then separated from the suspended microorganisms and was measured by an electrochemical method, using ferricyanide as a mediator. The current signal obtained represents the reoxidation of ferrocyanide, which was transformed to inhibiting efficiency, IC50, as a quantitative measure of toxicity. The IC50 values measured were 410, 570 and 830 mg/L for sodium nitrite, borax and aluminum potassium sulfate, respectively. The results show that the toxicity sequence for these three food additives is consistent with the value reported by other methods. Furthermore, the order of damage degree to the microorganism was also observed to be: sodium nitrite > borax > aluminum potassium sulfate > blank, according to the atomic force microscopy images of E. coli after being incubated for 3 hr with the toxic compound in buffer solutions. The electrochemical method is expected to be a sensitive and simple alternative to toxicity screening for chemical food additives.

/OTHER TOXICITY INFORMATION/  Urban ants are a worldwide critical household pests, and efforts to control them usually involve the use of alimentary baits containing slow-acting insecticides. A common toxicant used is boron, either as borax or boric acid. However, the presence of these compounds can affect the consumption of baits by reducing their acceptance and ingestion. Moreover, as feeding motivation varies widely, according not only to food properties but also to colony conditions, bait consumption might be diminished further in certain situations. In this study, ... the feeding response of ants toward two boron toxic baits (boric acid and borax) in low motivation situations that enhance any possible phago-deterrence the baits may produce /were compared/. Most studies investigating bait ingestion evaluate whole nests or groups of ants; here, /they/ analyzed the individual ingestion behavior and mortality of the Argentine ant, Linepithema humile (Mayr), and the carpenter ant, Camponotus mus (Roger), for two boron baits, to detect which compound generates a higher rejection in each of these species. Although these two species have similar feeding habits, /these/ results showed that ants under low motivation conditions reduced the acceptance and consumption of the toxic baits asymmetrically. While L. humile mostly rejected the borax, C. mus rejected the boric acid. These results denote the importance of considering the preference of each species when developing a pest management strategy.

plant_translocations.content: The investigation highlights the translocation patterns of borax applied foliarly in plants, indicating limited penetration and translocation rates within the foliage. The study reveals that foliar uptake of borax was relatively low, reaching only about 10% within 48 hours post-treatment and 12.2% after 12 days. Variability in uptake rates was noticeable, with higher consistency observed in plants treated with Solubor. Interestingly, the study reported substantial differences in foliar uptake among various plant species, with some showing near-complete uptake within 24 hours while others only absorbed a minute fraction of the applied borax. Additionally, the translocation of borax from treated leaves to non-treated aerial parts and roots increased notably over time, suggesting a gradual redistribution. Chemical composition of the applied solution influenced borax distribution within non-treated parts shortly after application but became indistinguishable between treatments after 12 days. The study underscores the mobility of foliar-applied borax, albeit not as rapid as reported in certain cases, highlighting the complexity of its translocation, which is influenced by factors like leaf age and plant boron supply. The research calls for further exploration to elucidate the diverse translocation mechanisms among plant species and to clarify the nature of soluble boron complexes involved in its phloem mobility. This emphasizes the need for continued investigations into formulations, additives, and environmental factors to enhance borax uptake efficiency in foliar treatments, particularly focusing on its translocation patterns across different plant species and climatic conditions.

method.Apply Location: Foliar application on the midrib of one of the pair of first leaves.
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds were germinated in Petri dishes and then planted in pots (10 seeds pot-1) containing compost (sedge and sphagnum peat) in a controlled climate chamber with a temperature of 22/15°C, humidity of 70/90%, and photoperiod of 16/8h.
method.Chemical preparation: Boron solutions enriched with 10B, made up to a concentration of 20 mM (0.202 g L-1); Use four different lOB enriched products: boric acid, borax decahydrate, high-solubility concentrate of sodium borate (Solubor) and an organic solution containing B (Cultibor).
method.Received pesticide of plant: Each 40 uL deposit corresponded to 0.8 umol of B or 8.08 ug of total B deposited per plant treated.
method.Other Information: Each boron solution was applied to 12 plants, with a total of 8 plants treated with distilled water serving as controls.
